Posts.Content: Hi, I got my pathology results on Thursday and I'm feeling rather confused. They said results were good, but I'm not feeling particularly elated! I'm ER and PR positive 8/8 and HER2 negative (this was previously borderline). Waiting for one more test on the HER2 but surgeon believes it will be negative. I had 7 grade 2 invasive tumours (NST, lobular and mucusious - I can't spell it!) and the biggest invasive one was 1.3cm. In between all the invasive tumours we're lots of DCIS. The total area of the tumours was 12.5 cm.  I had a SNB and all 4 taken were clear, and the report says no lymphatic/vascular invasion. It's believed to have been contained in the breast.  I had a mastectomy and when I asked about margins the surgeon said mastectomy margins are always clear. I asked if the tumour was near my chest wall because I had  (still have) pain in the centre of my chest (bone). I was told there was nothing to worry about.  As for my treatment the surgeon said I won't need chemotherapy or radiotherapy - he passed this on from the oncologist. Whom I will not meet because I don't need treatment. I asked would I get chemotherapy to mop up any strays that might have broken off and floated elsewhere. The answer was no. My treatment will be hormone therapy medication. I asked if it came back would it be incurable, he said yes it would be incurable.  As for the oncotype test, my case doesn't meet the criteria for sending it off. I've not been referred for any body scans. I literally feel like I was plopped on a conveyor belt - you have cancer, your boob needs to come off (which is really uncomfortable by the way!), right here's your pills (haven't got them yet though) off you pop and pray it doesn't come back.
Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Sal, you've hit the nail on the head. It is going to take time to work through this. I've had texts saying hey it's out! You must be so relieved. I am... believe me I am and I'm so grateful that the scary 12cm mass has gone. The cancerous party has been shut down!!!  Dragonbear (I LOVE the name!), is good to know that the worries reduce with time. Did they grade/stage/ treat your cancer according to the biggest one or did they do that based on all 4 of them?  I think a lot of my fear stems from the experience of our friend who now a short while after her primary diagnosis has been diagnosed with mets despite her protests for more tests after her initial dx I've been urged to insist upon further testin on my entire body just to be absolutely certain that my treatment plan is the right one.
Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, yes emotional screw up disease! I thought I was a screw up but I've gone to new heights now. I feel like a liar at times, saying I'm okay... cancer is out, it was contained - all 7 bastards of them! But in my head it's 'what if a little bastard offspring escaped camp and is hiding out'.  Would it be irrational for me to beg for a bone scan and ct scan before they release me with drugs?  I have talked to my nurse and my new one too they've both said 'hey it's good news! You're likely to live to be a grandma, hell even a great grandma!!' I can't understand why I'm not jumping for joy!
Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Leolady, you're right ask ask ask... I'm going to write an intensive document with a shit load of questions! I want to know details of each little bastard at the party, why my sternum hurts and why the bleep does it hurt to breath. Then I think I can rest and focus on healing physically and emotionally and enjoying the bleep out of my life! Something else will probably niggle at me but I'll deal with that later! I've been feeling so frustrated these last few days, crossed even. I'm annoyed that my scar is so tight. My husband says that everything has moved so swiftly and we've not had time to process things. He thinks I need to loose my temper, get angry, blow it out before I can breathe and chill.  I hope this 3rd op is the last one for you. If not then I'm joining the gang and hunting down your surgeon! Recover well xx
Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Good morning, thank you Jo. Do you remember if your mum experienced sternum pain (or have you?).  Yes I've heard of someone like you. The lovely Optimist suggested it before. Now that things have calmed down appointments and operations wise I'll sit down and contact them this week. Xx

Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Under my armpit! Hee I did think about that... if I have a reconstruction would my new one stick up whilst my old old buried itself in my armpit! You've confirmed it for me!   Yeah time is needed... like you I didn't have a lump just a little weird bristling when something touched my breast. No cancer concerns went I went to the unit then BAM! There's a party! Chop chop! I'm a lopsided princess (coined by leolady!).  My mum, bless her, has seen enough of cancer she's nursed so many of us, been there at the very end for some. It's impacted her in a huge way. On the plus side my dad is 3 time survivor, he had his 4th scare at the same time as my diagnosis, he got his scan results on the same day I got my pathology results and his were clear. I think all of us broke into tears of relief.   My mum said to me (before I got my results, this must have broken her heart) 'you can't look too far into the future, focus on what is right in front of you. Enjoy everything. If you don't, if you worry about the distant future you won't live your life to the fullest now'.  I should listen... but first I want to know what's going on in my chest!!  Thank you to all of you for taking the time to help calm my fears. Thank you xx
Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: You're right, at the moment it's on my mind all the time. Even if I do move on and heal emotionally it'll still be there lurking, ready to pounce on me occasionally. I remember my dad worrying at all sorts, and others couldn't understand. Sadly I now understand. I met a lady the day after my mastectomy and she had triple negative BC 18 years ago, she had no treatment other than a mastectomy and reconstruction. No sign of reoccurrence. Another lady was dx 25 years ago! I know most of us will go on to live long lives or lives that are lived to the max and enjoyed thoroughly... but jeez, cancer! It's one big scary monster.  On thing for certain I'm no longer going to wait until I retire, I'll no longer drown myself in work. If you're ready to move on then fantastic, that means this community has done its job  I have this idea (pinched from another site), if I am able to, of coming back every year, then every 5 years to offer hope and support for newly diagnosed people.  I think most people who've been treated and live the rest of their lives cancer free or are successfully managing cancer long term move on  And those of us that are newly diagnosed rarely see the positive stories only the scary ones. Xx

Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Hi, are we still able to get private health insurance even if we've had cancer?  Xx
Posts.Title: Is a Bone Scan after 5 years on Anastrozole a given?

Posts.Content: I'm not looking right now but I am considering it.  It all depends on my next appointment. I haven't familiarise myself with NHS vs private cancer prevention/reoccurrence care yet or the drugs that are out there. All I know is that tamoxifen is the given for people my age, and that it carries risks in itself.  Xx
Posts.Title: Is a Bone Scan after 5 years on Anastrozole a given?

Posts.Content: Would the insurance include the hormone therapy? I often wonder if on the NHS what happens after the 5 or 10 years on the Tamoxifen (I'm premenopausal 41yrs)... does my risk increase again or do they review medication needs?  I won't be assigned to an oncologist because I won't benefit Rads or chemo but will definitely be put on medication. What is kadcyla?
Posts.Title: Is a Bone Scan after 5 years on Anastrozole a given?

Posts.Content: That's a bit rubbish that they've refused you. It's your body. My op is in 2 days so no chance of a bilateral then. But I'm hoping to see someone soon after to discuss removing the other, hopefully I'll get a reply to my email soon now that the holidays are over.  I was reading a thread earlier where people had asked for proplatyc (I can't spell it!) mastectomy and had to have several discussions and meet with a psychiatrist before they were approved. One lady said having the bilateral was the best thing she ever did.  I think one of them said that they are more likely to accept request for bilateral if it is because you want symmetry not because of fear rushing you to make a rash decision.
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy (and pain in healthy breast)

Posts.Content: Hi, for all your input. Seems I'm not the only one that wants it off.  Jo, I can understand the wait until I'm not in the middle of treatments to make the decision. I feel I will still want it off though.  Jo jo, that makes sense. I view my breast differently now.  Weeble mum, surely they'd let you have the offer off of having a bra on hurts your ribs.  I'm curious, how often do you have chemo? What was your original diagnosis? No worries if you prefer not to say. My friend has been diagnosed with bone mets too.  Xx
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy (and pain in healthy breast)

Posts.Content: I'm seriously considering having my right breast off as well as my poorly left breast. No abnormal tissue was detected on the ultrasound and mammogram for the right but in the last few weeks my whole chest is hurting, including my right breast, and both armpits feel heated. I'm wondering if I'm holding myself differently and affecting my chest muscles, hence the soreness.  Has anyone else experienced this?  This isn't the only reason I want the other one off too. I'm fairly ample and my surgeon said that the reconstruction wouldn't match the right breast. By having both symmetrical I'll feel better. Plus I've been looking at some awesome flowery tattoos to cover the scars.  Anyone else requested bilateral mastectomy and glad they did it? Xx
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy (and pain in healthy breast)

Posts.Content: I forgot to ask... for those that have had bilateral mastectomy how have you been monitored for reoccurrence?
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy (and pain in healthy breast)

Posts.Content: Hi Glitch,  I hadn't heard of them, thank you I will have a look at their site. I'm hoping to have a recon later but I've not definitely decided as I've always wanted to go braless!
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy (and pain in healthy breast)

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy, I'm really sorry I missed this reply! Thank you for sharing your story with me.  Xx
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy (and pain in healthy breast)

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, I'm not as far along as you but I can understand your fear. I think many of us do. I've decided (haven't acted on it yet) to write to sheets of questions ready for when I get my results after mastectomy, one will be a list of questions if the results come back as no node involvement or spread and the second is if there is node involvement.  The aim of the questions is to go away from that appointment with every aspect of my fears and concerns answered - whats the plan for keeping me cancer free and hormones at bay. I saw a breast nurse this morning for my pre opt and she said that if there is no node involvement then that is very good, and if there is node involvement it's still okay as they adjust the treatment. She said in both cases people have survived and lived to old age.  A gentleman friend of mine has had cancer 3 times and in each case he has battled and won. My father also had cancer 3 times, first one 21 years ago and now he's 75. Take care and hopefully over time your fears will settle. You have a good result xx
Posts.Title: Can’t stop worrying

Posts.Content: It's okay to worry, think we all do. I'm worrying because I'm not going to get an oncologist appointment. I've no reassurance through treatments that it won't come back. Someone said to me, we can't  change what is but we can change how we perceive it.  Maybe looking into the oncotype test and the endopredict test. They might help you to decide which treatments would benefit you?  Hopefully by the end of Monday you'll be more relaxed when you know what the plan is to prevent reoccurrence. Good luck with your appointment.  Xx
Posts.Title: Can’t stop worrying

Posts.Content: Hi, You're welcome. I haven't actually got round to writing up my questions yet! I'm starting to feel afraid of my mastectomy (despite great reviews on my surgeon), and like you I'm worrying what if they're wrong about my node involvement.  If you're ER positive you might get hormone treatment that would help prevent it coming back. I saw an article on cancer research uk about a clinical trial on aspirin to prevent cancer returning, its in phase 3 and the trials end 2021. They're studying 3 groups of patients - one group on normal aspirin dose, another on double aspirin dose and the latter on a placebo. Be interesting to know if it works. It's tiring all this worry :)  All the best for your results
Posts.Title: Can’t stop worrying

Posts.Content: I'm loving all these crafty posts! The moon hare, and ladies in beautiful floaty dresses, quilt, doll, jumper... they're all fantastic.  I'm a screen printer, I print upto 2 meters by 2 meters of fabric at a time but haven't been able to do any printing for a while because of the thingybob that got lobbed off!  I've not done anything crafty since this journey began, but tonight I made myself some cold porcelain ready for tomorrow. Plan to make coasters but I've got a feeling it's going to go horribly wrong! Xx
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Love these! They're cute! Looking forward to seeing the knitted knocker  xx
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Kacang, the rug and the tapestry are GORGEOUS! Xx
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: I’m really sorry to read this heartbreaking news, I hope you defy the odds too. I have 4 raise lymph nodes on both sides of my neck. They terrify me. What was it that made them decide your lymph nodes were normal reactive nodes? Xx
Posts.Title: Breast lump - frightened and miserable.

Posts.Content: It was his liver that the operated on. No idea why it shrank though.
Posts.Title: Breast lump - frightened and miserable.

Posts.Content: Hi, How did you get on with your results for your neck nodes? xx
Posts.Title: Breast lump - frightened and miserable.

Posts.Content: I’m sorry you’re going through this  it’s similar to mine... neck nodes and an armpit thing. They’re investigating the armpit thing now.  I believe in food as medicine :) I changed my diet too. I don’t know if it’s helping but it’s definitely helping me mentally. Plus I feel strong and full of energy. I slipped up recently and felt terrible and tired!  Have you heard of the oco protocol? I’ve been looking into that and cbd oil for my dad who is considered incurable. This might help you a little, a male friend was diagnosed with breast cancer last year, when they finally cottoned on that it was BC it had spread into bones and distant organs. He decided to stop chemotherapy etc and was given until Xmas 2017. He’s still here... I’m not sure what he is doing but the tumours are shrinking. They shrank enough that the surgeons agreed to operate to remove the main tumours.  I contacted a lady called Ruth Hiedrich, she had secondary BC over 30 years ago. I found her really supportive and responded quickly to my emails. I wish you the very best  xx
Posts.Title: Breast lump - frightened and miserable.
